description: From Middle French volubile, from Latin volūbilis (“rolling”), from volvō (“roll”).

adjectives.description: voluble (comparative more voluble, superlative most voluble)

entries.meaning: (of a person or a manner of speaking) Fluent or having a ready flow of speech.
examples: Synonyms: garrulous, loquacious, tonguey; see also Thesaurus:talkative

entries.meaning: Of thoughts, feelings, or something that is expressed: expressed readily or at length and in a fluent manner.
examples: [H]e heard the voice of the drunken woman, now sober, poured out in voluble remorse, and in voluble promise of amendment for the future, to every one who passed, if they would let her off easy.

entries.meaning: Easily rolling or turning; having a fluid, undulating motion.
(botany) Twisting and turning like a vine.
